storyInfo: April bumps into a Messenger talking with Ansel on her way back from a mission. She curiously strikes up a conversation with Ansel. The discussion leads her to some realizations she had never thought about before.

attributes.content: Phew, that mission got me all sweaty.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I’d better hurry home and shower.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh, who’s that over there...?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Alright, that’s the letter and every last cent accounted for.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Thanks a lot.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Hah, don’t worry about it. You’re a very good customer. Pretty much your whole family knows me by now.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: But you haven’t been back in a while, huh? Why not take a trip home? Your uncle’s gonna ask me to drag you back to Rim Billiton as soon as he sees me.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Not that I’m one to talk, the way I’ve been running around for a year and change. But you know all the letters in the world can’t compare with you going home in person.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: ...I know. It’s just, there’s still patients here who need me.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: When I have some free time, I’ll go back.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Well, I think you’ve got a handle on it, so I’ll leave it here for now.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Anyway, I’ll check over the letters again and then head out.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Need any goodies? Or just the usual?
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Yes, get a box of those peppermint candies from the shop below my home.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Sure.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Sorry, Uncle...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: So they’ve got Messengers at Rhodes Island too.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Have we been introduced...?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I’m new here, codename’s April. But you can call me April.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Nice to meet you, April. I’m Ansel, from Medical.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: There are lots of Messenger at Rhodes Island. And Messengers like the one just now aren’t our operators, they’re Messengers who exclusively serve us Rhodes Islanders.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: What’s the difference?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: We have some Messengers who do become operators. Oh, like Angelina. Do you know her?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Yeah. She’s a Messenger girl, about my age?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Right. A lot of Messengers get sick and end up working for us as operators to offset the cost of treatment. That’s what happened with Angelina.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Oh, me too.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Yes. So you know the cost of Oripathy treatment is by no means low. There are all kinds of people from all walks of life here on the ship for more or less the same reason.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Isn’t that pretty much the same as becoming a Messenger here though?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Ahaha. I guess it is kind of confusing, but no.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Because Messenger work doesn’t involve much contact with other people, and you’re always traveling all around, you can still do it even after becoming Infected.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Basically, most people aren’t going to know if the person bringing them their mail is Infected or not...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: The point is they can keep doing their work same as they always were, as long as they come to Rhodes Island for regular treatment.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Huh. So they can just like, do their own thing?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Exactly. We usually give operators like that some long-term field work missions.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: And they tend to use Rhodes Island as a waystation for their work. And if they happen to be going near some friends or relatives of our operators, we’ll usually ask them to bring a letter or something.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But for someone like me, who writes home regularly, I need something more predictable.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: With very few Messengers from Rim Billiton at Rhodes Island right now.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Whew, it all feels so loose... I couldn’t imagine anything like that at my old company.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Anything like what?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: The employees having so much freedom! There must be some folks who come by once and never come back, right?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: You’re a sharp one. That does happen sometimes, and we do follow up on it. But no matter what happens, you can’t leave a patient unattended.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: You’re a real good person, Dr. Ansel.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Thanks. I’m just here to help people.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But that means Rhodes Island definitely needs some dedicated Messengers.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I never thought about this stuff before.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Say, April, you’re from Rim Billiton too, aren’t you?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Yep. I’m from the south side of Steel Robot City.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh, I know that place. Your hometown always tops the annual charts in ore production.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Yeah, that’s home. We’re supposed to be really proud of that productivity, but I can’t say it does much for me.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I’m from Iron Fist City. Do you have any relatives back home you need to contact?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Nope.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: My parents died in a mine accident when I was little. The company raised me.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: When I grew up, I worked for them as a hunter. It didn’t pay great, but I got by, until I caught Oripathy...
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: ...I’m sorry.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Nah, it’s fine.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I’ve heard that Rim Billiton’s companies actually treat the Infected pretty decently?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Because of how important the mining industry is, people back home end up coming into contact with Oripathy a lot more than in other countries...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: That’s what I thought at first, but after living through it, I was so, so wrong.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: They like to talk about all the benefits they offer, but down in the fine print they have all kinds of deductibles and copays. And once they know you’ve got Oripathy, you’ll suddenly find all your work drying up.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oripathy sufferers on their own, like me, just can’t survive.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh... I had no idea.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: No wonder so many of my old workmates who caught Oripathy just disappeared...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Anyway, I lost my company ID and the lease on my room, so there’s nothing for me back in Rim Billiton anymore.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Hey now, don’t you give me that look, Dr. Ansel. I can’t stand pity.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I made it to Rhodes Island, didn’t I?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I guess you did.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Anyways, I thought you looked kinda sad when you were sending that letter. Did something happen?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh, but you don’t have to tell me if it’s something really personal. And I won’t tell anyone either!
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: April, did you have lunch yet?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: No, I just got back from a mission. I was about to go take a shower.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Let me buy you lunch. This is a pretty long story.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Huh? Okay.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Wow, Dr. Ansel, you sure eat healthy.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: It comes with the job, I guess. And you can drop the 'doctor', just Ansel is fine. We’re pretty much the same age, right?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Okay~
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Eat up, first. We’ll get into it after we’ve taken the edge off.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Sure.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: ...I always say I wish I could see my family, but the truth is I don’t really want to go back.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Why?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: There’s some stuff I don’t want to deal with.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I have three older brothers and one baby sister, but my parents are long gone. Mom, to lung disease. Dad, overwork.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But I had it better than you. By the time they went, my brothers were old enough to work.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I was the only one still too young. So when he died, my dad had me sent to live with my uncle, his older brother. My sister went to his younger brother.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Yeah, that happens a lot. If I had any relatives, I’d have ended up like that.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: My dad once told me all our relatives went to other cities.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: So you don’t wanna go back because your uncle was bad to you?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: No. My uncle was a manager at a small company. He was serious and strict, but he treated me well, really just like his own son.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: It’s just...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: He didn’t want me to become a doctor.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Oh.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: When I was little, I helped out at Uncle’s company. He was grooming me to take over his job.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I didn’t listen to him. I decided to become a doctor, and went far away to Rhodes Island.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Woah. So you’re a runaway, Ansel?!
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Ahaha, no, I wouldn’t go that far.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: There was some time between my decision to study medicine and me actually coming to Rhodes Island.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I talked it over with Uncle many times. Sometimes our conversations got pretty heated.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But in the end, he respected my choice, and agreed I could become a doctor.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I get where he’s coming from. I never got the impression it was easy to practice medicine in Rim Billiton.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Right. First, it’s tough to get started. Then, it’s tough to keep going.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: A lot of mine doctors only have the most basic medical training.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: It definitely wouldn’t be as stable a life as working for Uncle’s company, and it’d be hard to find a job.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I seriously considered going with his plan. It really isn’t a bad place to work.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: And he did so much for me. I felt like I couldn’t let him down.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Sure, that makes sense. But everyone has a dream.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: It sounds like your uncle is a real good bloke, though. If my mom and dad were still around, I don’t think they’d be okay with something like that.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Right. And in the end, I followed through on my decision.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But Uncle isn’t the type to keep his feelings bottled up inside. He’s been with the company for half his life, and he still hopes I’ll go back to continue his work someday.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I’ve been back twice, and it’s always hard.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: And my brothers are even more opposed to what I do. But I send them money, so they keep their mouths shut.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: My sister, on the other hand, is pretty supportive.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I can’t really relate to any of that.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Let’s just say everybody’s got baggage.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I think I’m doing the right thing. And Rhodes Island treats me well.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But... it is what it is.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: There’s nothing I can do to change how Uncle feels.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I can only work harder and do better for myself, and my own goals.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: And one day I’ll be able to go back, puff out my chest and say: 'Look, Uncle, see how many people I’ve saved? I made a huge contribution to the fight against Oripathy.'
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: ...But I guess by then I’ll probably be brave enough to just face him anyway.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Soft and weak as you look, Ansel, who would’ve thought you’ve got all this going on?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I can’t tell if that’s supposed to be a compliment.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Of course it is.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Hah, alright, then.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But it sounds like you actually do want to go back home?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: ...I guess I do.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Going around the world with Rhodes Island is a great way to broaden your horizons, but no matter what happens, Rim Billiton is still my home.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I miss the giant smoke stacks, the din of machinery, the miners and their work chants, the noisy streets...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Maybe someday I’ll leave Rhodes and head back home to practice medicine.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Oh...
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: What is it?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Nothing. I was just thinking about how even though I say I don’t miss Rim Billiton at all, I don’t know if maybe I would go back.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Ansel, do you know where my codename comes from?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: April is like, a month? Fourth one on the calendar?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Yes, but also no. It’s the name of a song about spring.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I never felt like I liked Rim Billiton. I don’t like any of the stuff you’ve been talking about.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: My memories of home are all dark and dusty, I feel like I can barely breathe when I remember them.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Life wasn’t easy even before I got Oripathy.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I had to show up to the office every day, and then go out with the team whenever they had a job.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I made some money, but it was real hard out there. A ten day trip was common, and sometimes we’d even be gone for a month or two.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: And it’s not like there was much to do when we didn’t have a job either.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: The bands I liked were in other countries and cosmetics would only show up in magazines.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: With all the factories polluting the air, I had to put so much into my skin care routine.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Those factories, and even just the streets were so noisy they’d wake me up in the middle of the night.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: And would you believe my apartment was so lousy I’d run out of water right in the middle of a shower sometimes?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Phew, those don’t sound like good memories...
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But, when I really think about it, there were good times too.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: It was a ruthless, cutthroat company for sure, but they took care of me for years. I don’t know what the upper management was like, but I remember when I went to the office to talk about my benefits, the people there definitely weren’t happy about what they had to do.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: My neighbors had their issues, but they still helped me. Old Man Perot upstairs was always so mean to everyone, but he started giving me food after he found out I was sick.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh, but Old Mrs. Lolo downstairs was the worst. She spat whenever she saw me.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: The supermarket down there had all kinds of good stuff on rotation too. Speaking of, I don’t think I’ve ever seen meatballs like that anywhere else. Those were super tasty.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: And of course, the time I spent with mom and dad when I was little was real happy.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I know what’s going on here, I’m just getting a strong hit of nostalgia.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Hahaha, maybe.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But still, I think we can never really abandon our roots.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: When I came to Rhodes Island, I learned how vast our world is, and all the wonderful ways one can live a life.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I’ve thought about trying another life for myself, like becoming a Vanguard Operator or a caster. Or going into civilian work.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: And I could just choose a new life for myself. No one would stop me.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But in the end, I decided to keep on practicing medicine.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I was born in Rim Billiton, and I grew up among the workers. Unless I suddenly woke up with amnesia someday, there’s no way I could deny my past.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Speaking of amnesia, did I hear that the Doctor has it?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh, yes. That’s no secret.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Going with what you said earlier, do you think the Doctor could choose a new life?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: ...I think that would be pretty hard.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I don’t know the Doctor’s past, but Amiya, Dr. Kal'tsit, and lots of others do.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I think a lot of the things the Doctor does are not exactly done by choice.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: So I guess that means even if you do lose your memory, you’re still stuck with your past.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Yeah. How did we get here from talking about hometowns?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Anyway, your hometown is definitely the most important part of your past.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Right. But it’s not really the town itself that matters, it’s the mark left on you by the time you spent there.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I could’ve given up that mark, but I decided to hold onto it.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: What about you?
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Hm...
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I dunno. I never thought about it before.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Doesn’t matter. We’re still young. We’ve got a lot of time to figure that one out.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: But I guess I didn’t leave Rim Billiton to get away from that life, at least.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: If I could’ve kept on living there, I probably would’ve. I just didn’t have a choice.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I suffered a lot after I became Infected, yeah, but I can’t keep on hating people, and saying stuff like I hate Rim Billiton.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: That’s totally normal. When someone gets Infected, his whole worldview doesn’t turn on a dime.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: You’ll have a better understanding after you live at Rhodes Island for a while. At least for now, we can keep talking about home, and our past.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Right, well, I guess I have to admit I’m the accepting type, huh?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I probably won’t say I like Rim Billiton, but I can say I like Steel Robot City.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I’ll never forget how, whenever I was feeling down, I’d head up to the roof of my apartment building.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: It wasn’t that tall. There were other, taller ones around.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: And I’d feel fenced in, trapped by those tall buildings around me. Like the piece of sky straight up above me was all I could see.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: But it was also kind of reassuring, because I don’t need a lot of space. I don’t like having too many choices. A little coziness is just right for me.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I’d look around and see what the neighbors were doing. Sometimes I’d see something fun, sometimes I wouldn’t. But it didn’t matter.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Then I’d lie down in the middle of the rooftop, put on my headphones, and play my favorite song: 'April'. I’d think about whatever, and take a nice nap.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: By the time I woke up, most of my worries would be gone.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Sounds great.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: It was. I wish I could find a place like that here, but the Rhodes Island deck is just too wide and open for me.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: I’ll point you towards an operator named Kroos. She’s got a lot of experience finding places to slack off.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Really? That’d be great! I’ll go find her in a bit!
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: But after all that, I do kinda feel like I want to go back home.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: It’s your fault.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Hah, well, I’m sorry.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: I’ll set that aside for now. I’m still new here. I can’t go taking a vacation right away.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Oh, I know!
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Is that Messenger you hired to send your letter gone yet?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Probably not. I think he’s here until tomorrow.
attributes.name: Ansel

attributes.content: Great, I’ll go get him!
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Mr. Messenger! You’re going to Rim Billiton, right?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Sure am, little Cautus. Do you want to send something?
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: April’s fine. But it’s not a letter, I was hoping you could do something for me?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: What?
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: When you’re in Rim Billiton, could you please go to the top of a tall building and take a picture of the view up there?
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Huh? Kind of a weird request.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: ...But it doesn’t sound hard. I could probably do that.
attributes.name: Rhodes Island Messenger

attributes.content: Oh, thank you so much!
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: My hometown, my past... turns out I care more than I thought I did.
attributes.name: April

attributes.content: Well, anyway, what really matters now is meeting that Kroos girl. Finding a nice place to nap is a much more realistic goal than going home!
attributes.name: April
